abstract.p: New York Mets manager Bobby Valentine, while saying left field umpire Tim McClelland made right call on Todd Zeile's near-homer in Game 1 of World Series, says McClelland's inactivity may have caused base-running mistake by Timo Perez (S)

block.p: While saying Tim McClelland, the left-field umpire in Game 1, made the right call on Todd Zeile's near-homer on Saturday, Bobby Valentine said McClelland's inactivity may have caused a base-running mistake by Timo Perez.

When Zeile's two-out drive in the sixth inning deflected off the top of the left-field wall and stayed in play, Perez hesitated on the bases, thinking the ball was a homer. He ended up being thrown out at home.

While saying Tim McClelland, the left-field umpire in Game 1, made the right call on Todd Zeile's near-homer on Saturday, Bobby Valentine said McClelland's inactivity may have caused a base-running mistake by Timo Perez.

When Zeile's two-out drive in the sixth inning deflected off the top of the left-field wall and stayed in play, Perez hesitated on the bases, thinking the ball was a homer. He ended up being thrown out at home.
''If he does this,'' Valentine said of McClelland, spreading his arms in a ''safe'' motion, ''Timo keeps running.''
''Not to put any blame on the umpire, but the call is a safe call, and the players probably react a lot quicker if it's a safe call.'' he said.
Perez, however, said he never looked at the umpire. ''I was sure it was a home run, and I was confused,'' he said.
